messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Hey, why didn’t you answer my texts last night?

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I was on a call with my sister. It went on longer than I expected.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You know I don’t like when you talk to other people that late. It makes me feel like I’m not your priority.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: She was going through something serious, I couldn’t just hang up.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: If I’m important to you, you’d tell her you have someone waiting. You’re supposed to put me first.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I do put you first most of the time. This was just one night.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: One night becomes many. Remember last week when you stayed late at work? Same thing. You keep choosing others over me.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I stayed late because my manager asked me to. I need my job.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: If you really cared, you’d push back. But fine, if I’m not that important, maybe I should stop trying so hard.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: That’s not what I said. I’m just trying to balance things.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Balancing shouldn’t mean I come last. From now on I want you to check with me before you make plans with anyone else, okay?

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: That feels a bit intense… but I guess I can try.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: It’s not intense. It’s what people do when they actually care about their partner’s feelings.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You didn’t send me your location when you went out with your coworkers today.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: It was just lunch at the cafe across the street. I didn’t think it was a big deal.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: We talked about this. I need to know where you are. It’s for your safety.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I understand safety, but I checked in before I left. Isn’t that enough?

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: No, because you still chose not to do the one simple thing I asked. It’s like you’re testing how far you can push me.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I’m not trying to push you. I just wanted to enjoy lunch without constantly updating my phone.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: If you cared about my peace of mind, you’d send the location. It takes two seconds. Why is that so hard for you?

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I don’t want to feel monitored all the time. It makes me uncomfortable.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: So your comfort is more important than my anxiety? Nice to know. I guess I’ll just sit here worried sick while you do whatever you want.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: That’s not fair. I’m trying to be considerate.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Then prove it. From now on, share your location anytime you leave the house, and call me when you arrive and when you leave. If you can’t do that, I don’t see how this can work.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Okay… I’ll do it.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Why did you wear that outfit to the party? You know it makes me uncomfortable.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I like that dress. I wore it because it makes me feel confident.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Confident? It just makes people stare. I saw the way they were looking at you.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I can’t control how others look. I just wanted to feel good about myself.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: If you respected me, you wouldn’t wear things that invite that kind of attention.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: So I’m being disrespectful by choosing my clothes?

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Yes, because you know it bothers me and you did it anyway. It feels like you’re trying to make me jealous.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I’m not trying to make you jealous. I just want to express myself.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: If you want this relationship to last, you’ll stop with the revealing outfits and run what you wear by me first. I’m only asking because I care about us.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: That sounds really controlling.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Call it whatever you want. I call it setting standards. If you can’t handle that, maybe you aren’t ready for something serious.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: …I don’t know what to say right now.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Why are you upset again? It’s always something with you.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I’m hurt by how you talked to me in front of your friends. You made jokes about my anxiety.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: They were just jokes. Everyone laughed. You’re too sensitive.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: It didn’t feel like a joke to me. You shared personal stuff I trusted you with.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I’m the only one who puts up with you and your panic attacks, and this is the thanks I get? You want me to walk on eggshells now?

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: That’s not what I’m saying. I just wanted you to have my back.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I am the only one who has your back. No one else would stay with you if they saw everything I deal with.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: That’s really harsh…

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: It’s reality. Instead of complaining, maybe be grateful I’m still here. Most people would’ve left a long time ago.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I didn’t realize you resented me like that.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I don’t resent you. I’m just tired of being painted as the villain when I’m the only one strong enough to handle you.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I just wanted you to apologize.

messages.speaker: speaker B
messages.text: Now I feel even smaller.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You’re mad at me again? What is it this time?

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You called me useless when I forgot to take the trash out. That really stung.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Well, if you can’t manage one small task, what am I supposed to think?

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Everyone forgets things. It doesn’t mean I’m useless.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You forget a lot more than ‘everyone.’ I handle all the important things while you screw up the simple ones.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I do a lot around here too. That’s not fair.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Like what? Making a mess in the kitchen and leaving your stuff everywhere? That’s not ‘a lot’.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You’re only pointing out what I do wrong. You never notice what I do right.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Maybe if you did something right more often, I’d notice. I’m not going to hand out gold stars for basic responsibilities.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Hearing that from you just makes me feel terrible about myself.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: If you feel terrible, maybe that’s the push you need to finally get it together.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: That doesn’t feel like support. It feels like you’re tearing me down.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You’re crying again? Over what I said?

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You told me I’m a burden and that everyone else thinks I’m annoying too.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I was just being honest. People get tired of your constant talking. Someone had to tell you.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You could’ve said it more kindly. It felt like you were attacking me.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You always twist everything into ‘attacks.’ I’m trying to help you be less… much.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Less much?

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Yes. Less overwhelming. Less needy. Less dramatic. It’s exhausting.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I didn’t know you felt that way about me.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I’ve dropped hints for months. But you don’t listen. You just cling harder.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I come to you because I trust you, not to be made to feel pathetic.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: If you don’t like my honesty, find someone else who’s willing to lie to you. I’m not changing the way I talk just because you can’t handle it.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I don’t even know how to respond to that.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You’re still bringing up that argument from last week?

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Because you said you never raised your voice, and you absolutely did. I remember it clearly.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: No, I didn’t. You’re exaggerating. I was calm the whole time.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I felt scared. My hands were shaking.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You always overreact. Just because you felt a certain way doesn’t mean it happened like that.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I’m not making it up.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You misremember things all the time. Your memory is terrible when you’re emotional. We’ve talked about this.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I might forget small details, but I wouldn’t invent you yelling at me.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I didn’t yell. You’re rewriting the story because it makes you feel justified in being upset.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Now I’m confused. I was so sure about what happened.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Exactly. You’re confusing yourself. Trust me, if I had raised my voice, I’d admit it. I didn’t. You’re wrong about this.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Maybe I am remembering it wrong… I don’t know anymore.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Why are you acting like I ignored you at the party?

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You barely spoke to me and kept whispering with that one friend. I felt shut out.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: That’s not what happened. I introduced you to everyone. You just stood there awkwardly.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You introduced me and then walked away. I ended up alone in the corner for most of the night.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: No, you chose to stand in the corner. I kept looking over and you wouldn’t join the conversation.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I don’t remember it like that at all.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Your memory is tinted by your insecurity. You always think people are leaving you out even when they’re not.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: It really felt like you left me out, though.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Feelings aren’t facts. The fact is, I did my best to include you. If you felt left out, that’s on you.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: So this is all just in my head?

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Pretty much. You need to stop inventing problems. It makes it hard to enjoy anything with you.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You keep saying I said you were ‘lazy,’ but I never used that word.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You told me I never do anything right and that you can’t rely on me. That’s basically calling me lazy.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: No, that’s you twisting my words. I only mentioned the dishes.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You said, ‘I can’t trust you to follow through on anything,’ remember?

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I don’t recall saying that. You’re putting words in my mouth again.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I remember standing in the kitchen and feeling crushed when you said it.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You ‘felt’ crushed, so now your brain filled in a dramatic line that I never actually spoke.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Why would I imagine something that specific?

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Because you like to cast yourself as the victim and me as the bad guy. You’ve done this before.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I’m not trying to make you the bad guy. I just want you to acknowledge what hurt me.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I’m not owning something I didn’t say. You really need to work on how you distort things.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I’m starting to question my own memory at this point.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Hey, you didn’t answer my call last night. I rang three times.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I was already in bed, and I’d told you I was going to sleep early. I keep asking you not to call after 11.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: It was important. I needed to vent, and you’re my friend.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I understand, but I’ve been clear that late-night calls drain me. I have to get up early.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Wow. So you’re one of those people now—too busy and rigid for a five-minute conversation.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: It’s not about being rigid. It’s about having a boundary around my sleep.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You know I don’t have many people to talk to. You shutting me down like this really hurts.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I’m not shutting you down. I’m asking you to call earlier or text first.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: So your schedule matters more than my mental health. Got it.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: That’s not what I said at all. I just need you to respect that I can’t be on-call 24/7.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Some friend. I always pick up when you need me, but apparently that isn’t mutual.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I appreciate when you’re there for me, but I still need limits. That doesn’t make me a bad friend.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You never told me your parents were coming over this weekend.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Because I didn’t plan on them staying here. I already said they should get a hotel.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: They just assumed they could crash in our apartment. I felt ambushed.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: My mom booked the hotel yesterday. I told you as soon as I knew they’d visit.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: But you didn’t ask how I felt about having them here all weekend. That’s still a boundary for me.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I thought you’d be okay meeting them for dinner and hanging out a bit. I didn’t think I needed to negotiate that.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: When it affects my whole weekend and my space, yeah, I want a say. I need time to recharge.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I guess I just wanted you to be flexible for once. They keep asking when they’ll see you again.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Being flexible doesn’t mean ignoring my limits. I told you big social plans need to be discussed.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I didn’t mean to steamroll you. I just got excited and said yes too quickly.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: It feels like my needs come second whenever your family is involved.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I hear you. Next time I’ll check in before confirming anything, okay?

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I noticed you went through my sketchbook again.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: It was just sitting on the table. I was curious. Your drawings are good.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I’ve told you that’s private. Some of those are really personal.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You’re overreacting. It’s not like I showed anyone. I’m your partner; why can’t I see them?

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Because I said I’m not ready to share them. That should be enough.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You expect intimacy from me but shut me out of your world. That doesn’t feel fair.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Having boundaries doesn’t mean shutting you out. It means I get to choose what I share and when.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I just want to feel included. Sometimes it feels like you keep whole parts of yourself hidden from me.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I’m allowed to have things that are just mine. Reading my stuff without asking is crossing a line.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I didn’t think it was a big deal. I won’t look again, but I wish you didn’t treat me like an intruder.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I wouldn’t if you asked first instead of assuming everything of mine is automatically yours to access.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Why did you get home at 8? I told you to be back by 6.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Mom, the study group ran late. I texted you that we were still working.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: That’s not the point. If you respected me, you’d leave when I said, text or no text.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: We had an exam review. I didn’t want to fall behind.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You don’t need those people. You have everything you need here. I don’t like you spending so much time with them.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: They’re just classmates. We’re literally studying.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I’ve raised you my way for 17 years. I know what’s good for you more than they do. From now on, no staying after school without my permission first.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: But you never say yes when I ask.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Because I can see what you can’t. You think they’re your friends, but they’re a distraction. I don’t want you going unless I approve it.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: It feels like you’re trying to control everything I do.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I’m protecting you. If you can’t follow my rules, I’ll just start picking you up right after class so there’s no ‘study group’ to worry about.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I saw the email from your advisor. Why are you talking about switching majors?

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Because I’m miserable in business. I want to go into design. I’ve told you that.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You’re not throwing away everything I’ve invested in you for some hobby. You’ll stick with finance like we agreed.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: We didn’t really agree. You just kept saying it was the only smart choice.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Because it is. You think I’m paying tuition so you can draw pictures? No. You’ll stay in the program or I cut off support, simple as that.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: So my options are do what you want or drop out?

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Your option is to follow the plan that actually leads somewhere. You can thank me later when you have a real job.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: It’s my life, though.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: As long as I’m funding it, it’s my decision. You deviating from the plan is not an option, understood?

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I don’t feel like I get a say in any of this.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You don’t, not right now. Do what I’m telling you and stop overcomplicating it.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You got a B again? What is wrong with you?

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: It was a hard exam. I studied all week.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Clearly not hard enough. Your cousin manages straight A’s and she doesn’t whine about it.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I’m trying my best. I thought a B wasn’t terrible.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Your ‘best’ is embarrassing. Do you enjoy disappointing me?

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: No… I just struggle with math.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You struggle with focus, that’s what you struggle with. You’re always on your phone or doodling nonsense instead of being serious.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: That’s not fair, I’ve been cutting back a lot.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: If you actually cared about your future, we wouldn’t be having this conversation every semester. I’m starting to think you’re just not smart enough for this.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: That really hurts to hear from you.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Maybe being a little hurt will finally wake you up. I’m tired of cheering for mediocrity.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Why are you crying over what I said? It was a joke.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You called me pathetic in front of your friends. They all laughed.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Because you were hovering and repeating the same story. You looked desperate for attention.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I was just trying to join the conversation.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You ruin every hangout by being weird. Nobody wants you there, I only let you tag along because Mom makes me.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: That’s really mean. You could’ve just asked me to give you space.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: If you weren’t so clueless, I wouldn’t have to spell it out. You’re like an annoying shadow that never gets the hint.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You make me feel like there’s something wrong with me.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Maybe if you actually listened and stopped being so awkward, people wouldn’t cringe when you show up.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You know I’m insecure already. Why do you keep saying things like that?

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Because sugarcoating hasn’t changed anything. Maybe hearing the truth this blunt will finally sink in.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Why are you so cold with me tonight?

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Because yesterday you called me a failure and said I was a disappointment. I haven’t been able to stop thinking about it.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I never said you were a failure. You’re putting words in my mouth.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You did. You were standing by the sink and you said, ‘You’re such a failure, I don’t know what to do with you.’

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: No, I said your choices were disappointing, not you as a person. You’re twisting it.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: That’s not how it sounded at all.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You always mishear things when you’re upset. You’ve done this since you were little. You build a whole drama in your head.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: It felt really real. I remember the exact words.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Feelings aren’t facts. If I actually called you a failure, don’t you think I’d remember? I’m your mother, I would never say that.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Now I don’t even know if I can trust my own memory.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Exactly. So stop punishing me for something that didn’t happen and just let it go.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You shoved me earlier when you got mad about the game. My shoulder still hurts.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I barely touched you. Stop being dramatic.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You slammed me against the door. I fell over.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: If I had slammed you, there’d be a bruise or something. You tripped over your own feet like you always do.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I know what being pushed feels like.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You don’t. You freak out anytime someone brushes past you. You’ve got this victim thing going on.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You were yelling and then you grabbed my arm.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I grabbed your arm to stop you from flailing the controller. You twisted away and fell. That’s on you.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: That’s not how it happened.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Your memory is ridiculous. Ask Mom, she’d laugh if you told her I ‘slammed’ you. You’re making up a whole story.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I’m starting to wonder if I imagined it being that rough.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Exactly. So maybe think before you accuse me next time.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Did you go through my desk drawer?

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: I was just looking for a pen. Why are you so intense about it?

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Because my journal was open on the bed when I came in. I never leave it like that.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Okay, I flipped through a few pages. You leave it unlocked; it’s not that serious.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: It’s extremely serious to me. Those are private thoughts.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You write about me in there. I wanted to see what you were saying.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: That doesn’t give you the right to read it. I’ve told you before not to touch my stuff without asking.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: We’re sisters. We share everything. Why are you acting like I’m some stranger?

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Because you crossed a line. I get to have things that are just mine.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: You’re being overdramatic. I was curious, that’s all.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Curious or not, it’s a boundary. If you can’t respect that, I’m going to start locking my room.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I saw those messages you were sending last night. We need to talk about your choices.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Wait, you went through my phone? Why would you do that?

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Because I’m your mother and I have a right to know what’s going on in your life.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: That doesn’t mean you can just grab my phone and read private conversations.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: You live under my roof. Privacy is earned, not assumed. If you have nothing to hide, this shouldn’t bother you.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: It bothers me because it feels like you don’t trust me at all.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: Trust is built. Sneaking around texting boys late at night doesn’t help.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: We were just talking. And even if we weren’t, you still should have asked before snooping.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: I don’t need permission to protect you. If that means checking your phone, I’ll do it. End of story.

messages.speaker: Speaker B
messages.text: Then I guess I’ll never feel safe keeping anything to myself in this house.

messages.speaker: Speaker A
messages.text: If you want more freedom, start by accepting that I set the boundaries, not you.
